article_title: Prominent whistle-blower lawyer takes aim at Silicon Valley
article_text:
Prominent whistle-blower lawyer takes aim at Silicon Valley

Photo: -, AFP / Getty Images An image grab taken from a video released by Wikileaks on October...

Look out, Silicon Valley. Eric Havian just might be gunning for you.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Thomas Lee
article_metadata.description: Armed with new federal laws (plus an old one) and a track record as one of the country’s best whistle-blower lawyers, Havian has his sights set on tech, an industry that has long enjoyed a relatively squeaky-clean reputation when it comes to corruption.  [...] just because Google adopted “don’t be evil” as its motto doesn’t mean people inside the search giant are not capable of ethical or legal lapses in judgment because ... well, they’re people.  [...] we’re seeing more government contracts are going to technology companies.  Federal whistle-blower laws, most notably the False Claims Act, encourage people working at companies that supply the U.S. government with products or services to report wrongdoing.  The U.S. economy had grown increasingly complex and connected to the global supply chain, and the government needed whistle-blowers again to help it detect fraud, Havian said.  An assistant U.S. attorney in San Francisco from 1987 to 1994, Havian eventually chose a private career in whistle-blower cases.  In 2009, Havian was lead counsel in a case in which big defense contractor Northrop Grumman paid a record $325 million settlement for selling the U.S. military defective parts used in spy satellites.  Two major laws passed under the Obama administration — the Affordable Care Act and the Dodd-Frank Act — opened up the health care and finance industries to whistle-blower scrutiny.  Tech companies are increasingly supplying the government with everything from cloud servers to software used by the military and intelligence communities.  An FBI employee was banished to an empty office because he alerted superiors to instances where managers allowed favorite employees to take birthdays off.  With the advent of mobile devices and cloud-based data, vast amounts of information, whether e-mails or corporate documents, can easily leave a building, Havian said.
